citation.article-title: Acetobacter xylinus sp. nov., nom. rev., for the cellulose-forming and cellulose-less acetate-oxidising acetic acid bacteria with the Q-10 system.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Acetobacter xylinus (Brown 1886) Yamada sp. nov., nom. rev.
Acetobacter xylinus (xylinus Latin adjective, woody, derived from xylon Greek nom., wood)
Synonym: Acetobacter aceti subsp. xylinum (Brown 1886) De Ley and Frateur 1974.
Gram-negative rods, 0.6-0.9 x 1.0-3.0 Î¼m, occurring singly, in pairs, in chains, or in small clusters.
Forms leathery, thick pellicle-forming colonies, however, smooth and glistening colonies are formed, when cellulose-forming activity is lost.
Acids are formed from glucose, xylose, galactose and ethanol.
Produces mostly 5-ketogluconate and 2-ketogluconate from glucose and dihydroxyacetone from glycerol.
DNA base composition ranges from 54.9 to 62.6 mol % G+ C.
Cellular fatty acid is of straight chain type containing C18:1 acid as major.
